item.title: Just started coding Java
item.dc:creator: @Disorder Disorder
item.description:
@Disorder wrote:

If you decide to get a book, I recommend these two. Having read both volumes, I have to say: excellent books.

amazon.com

Core Java, Volume I--Fundamentals (8th Edition)

Cay S. Horstmann, Gary Cornell

This revised edition of the classic Core Java™, Volume I–Fundamentals , is the definitive guide to Java for serious programmers who want to put Java to work on real projects.   Fully updated for the n ...

4.0 out of 5 stars, ISBN: 978-0132354769, Prentice Hall, September 21, 2007


amazon.com

Core Java, Vol. 2: Advanced Features, 8th Edition

Cay S. Horstmann, Gary Cornell

The revised edition of the classic Core Java™, Volume II–Advanced Features, covers advanced user-interface programming and the enterprise features of the Java SE 6 platform. Like Volume I (which cover ...

4.3 out of 5 stars, ISBN: 978-0132354790, Prentice Hall, April 18, 2008

There’s not much in java 7 so these books are still good to go.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Xellium wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:7, topic:444200”][quote author=sw3ldn link=topic=546889.msg4009646#msg4009646 date=1339031343]

How about you buy a book and read it? You practise all the presented knowledge step by step.

yeah what he said i recommend the “java for dummies” series because it breaks everything down nice and slow and it helps you understand all the important things, i think its like 20 dollars on amazon!
[/quote]
a more reputable, proven book would be my suggestion…[/quote]

I bought it. I learned more lurking for a week on mopar, then out of the whole book. The custom JCreator was nice though.

item.title: Just started coding Java
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:1, topic:444209”]I haven’t played with Swing in quite a while, so I may be wrong.
Calling frame.pack() minimizes the area of the window; when you invoke frame.add(button), the window expands so that it may fit the button.
To avoid this, try removing the frame.pack() call.[/quote]
frame.pack() just eliminates unneeded canvas whitespace?

Read full topic

To avoid this, try removing the frame.pack() call.[/quote]

item.title: Just started coding Java
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

It’s the layout manager of frames. You need to either set it to null and hard-code the values in, or set a different layout manager besides the default.

Read full topic

item.title: Just started coding Java
item.description:
@202685 wrote:

Well the title says it, I’ve just started coding Java (Other than RSPS, Which I suck at)

I wanted to make a simple Swing GUI… So far I’ve got the GUI to open, I’ve got it named, but I’m trying to add the button, but i can’t make it a certain size… It just stays as big as the GUI window…

Here’s my code so far… (it’s my first code, don’t hate)

[code=java]import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.;

public class NewGUI extends ButtonListener {

private static void openGUI() {

	JFrame frame = new JFrame("New GUI");
	frame.setSize(500, 300);
	Dimension PanelID = new Dimension(500, 300); 
	Dimension PanelID2 = new  Dimension(10, 10); //FAIL
	frame.setPreferredSize(PanelID);
	frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

	frame.pack(); //IDK What This Does...
	frame.setVisible(true); 

	//JTextField field1 = new JTextField("Hello"); FUCK THAT
	//frame.add(field1); FUCK THAT
	JButton button1 = new JButton("Test");
	button1.setSize(PanelID2);
	frame.add(button1);
}

public static void main(String args[]) {
	openGUI();
}

}[/code]

The “extends ButtonListener” doesn’t do anything ATM…

So could anyone tell me why my button stays the same size as the screen?

Read full topic
